channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Oil Surges, US Futures Drop After Strikes on Iran: Markets Wrap
item.description: Markets were jolted by the US launching strikes on Iran’s nuclear sites over the weekend, a sharp escalation that sent oil prices surging and the dollar higher in early trading.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Burgess, Ruth Carson

media:content.media:description: Oil storage containers in Midland, Texas, US, on Thursday, Oct. 3, 2024. Oil steadied following its biggest one-day jump in almost a year as fears that Israel may decide to strike Iranian crude facilities in retaliation for a missile barrage kept the market on edge.

item.title: Dollar Gains in Early Trading as World Awaits Iran’s Response
item.description: The dollar strengthened in early trading as investors sought to shield against mounting geopolitical risks following the US strikes on Iran.
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani, Anya Andrianova, Macarena Munoz Montijano, Ruth Carson

item.title: Oil Soars as Trump’s Attack on Iran Ramps Up Risks to Supplies
item.description: Oil surged after the US struck Iran’s three main nuclear sites and threatened further attacks, exacerbating a crisis in the Middle East and stoking concerns that energy supplies from the region could be disrupted.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

media:content.media:description: Smoke from the Shahran oil depot, following a missile strike northwest of Tehran, on June 16. Photographer: ATTA KENARE/AFP

item.title: Two Supertankers U-Turn in Strait of Hormuz After US Strikes
item.description: Two supertankers both capable of hauling about 2 million barrels of crude U-turned in the Strait of Hormuz after US airstrikes on Iran raised the risk of a response that will ensnare commercial shipping in the region.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: An oil tanker in the Strait of Hormuz. Photographer: Kaveh Kazemi/Getty Images

item.title: Japan Flags Big Cut to Long-End Bond Issuance Before Risky Sale
item.description: Japan’s larger-than-expected cut to super-long bond issuance has potential to ease some upward pressure on yields just before an auction this week that risks reigniting turmoil in the debt market.
item.dc:creator: Mia Glass, Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: Mount Fuji and the Shinjuku skyline in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, Feb. 14, 2025. Japan is scheduled to release its fourth-quarter gross domestic product (GDP) figures on Feb. 17.

item.title: Fed’s Daly Says Employment, Inflation Risks Roughly in Balance
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly said she sees the central bank’s monetary policy stance as “in a good place” currently, with risks to its US employment and price stability mandates as roughly equal.
item.dc:creator: Maria Paula Mijares Torres, Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: Mary Daly, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, during the National Association of Business Economics (NABE) economic policy conference in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, Feb. 16, 2024. The theme of this year's annual meeting is Navigating Geopolitical Turbulence and Domestic Uncertainty. Photographer: Graeme Sloan/Bloomberg

item.title: Mild US Inflation Is Backdrop for Fed’s Powell on the Hill
item.description: US inflation probably inched higher in May, offering scant evidence of extensive tariff-related repercussions that the Federal Reserve expects to become more apparent later in the year.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 18, 2025. Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged and continued to pencil in two rate cuts in 2025, saying uncertainty over the economic outlook was still high but had diminished.

item.title: Largest US Grid Issues Energy Emergency Alert for Monday Heat
item.description: PJM Interconnection, which serves about 20% of Americans in the mid-Atlantic to the Midwest, declared an energy emergency alert with power demand expected to climb to a 14—year high amid intense heat.
item.dc:creator: Naureen S Malik

media:content.media:description: The sun rises behind the skyline of midtown Manhattan and the Empire State Building in New York City on June 19, 2025.

item.title: How a Cornered Iran Could Wreak Havoc on Global Oil Trade
item.description: US airstrikes on Iranian nuclear facilities are sharpening the focus on one option Iran has yet to really deploy in the conflict: disrupting regional oil trade, especially through the critical Strait of Hormuz.
item.dc:creator: Verity Ratcliffe, Grant Smith, Alex Longley, Julian Lee

item.title: Options Traders Wrestle With Stocks’ Muted Reaction to War Risk
item.description: The stock market’s recent calm in the face of rising geopolitical threats had left options traders with a conundrum: sell volatility and risk being blindsided should the Middle East conflict escalate; or buy it and bleed away premiums as actual moves stay subdued. That tension is set to ratchet even higher after the US attacked Iranian nuclear sites.
item.dc:creator: Christian Dass

media:content.media:description: Oil tankers are seen anchored in the Pacific Ocean in this aerial photograph taken above Long Beach, California, U.S., on Friday, May 1, 2020. The volume of oil on vessels located just offshore the state peaked at 26 million barrels over the weekend, about a quarter of the world's daily consumption, before dropping to 22 million barrels on Monday, according to Paris-based Kpler SAS, which tracks tanker traffic.

item.title: Billions of Fans Anticipate Netflix’s New Adventure
item.description: As the $76 billion industry evolves, everyone is racing to capture attention and market share through immersive experiences in a space dominated by traditional media players, Disney and NBCUniversal. While legacy parks rely on decades-old IP and massive capital investments, Netflix is tapping into fan obsession with shows like Stranger Things and Squid Game to launch live experiences in malls and cities worldwide. At the same time, family-owned Herschend is betting that old is gold to keep visitors coming back to parks like Silver Dollar City. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: How Will Iran Respond to Trump's Air Strikes?
item.description: The US carried out airstrikes on three nuclear sites in Iran, directly entering Israel's war with Tehran, despite President Donald Trump's promises to avoid new foreign conflicts. Trump says Iran's nuclear capabilities have been obliterated. Iran says the attacks were "outrageous." Bloomberg's Joumanna Bercetche reports on how Iran could respond and the reaction from the Middle East. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Hegseth and Gen. Caine Detail Air Strikes Against Iran
item.description: US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and General Dan Caine, the chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff, detail the strike against three Iranian nuclear facilities. Dubbed "Operation Midnight Hammer," it involved B-2 bombers, a submarine that launched Tomahawk cruise missiles and bunker-buster bombs. Hegseth says the mission was not about a regime change in Iran. They speak at the Pentagon. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Israeli Stocks Rise as Traders See US Hastening End to Conflict
item.description: Middle Eastern stocks rose on Sunday, led by Israel and Egypt, as the region’s traders bet the US strikes on Iran may accelerate the end of the conflict between the country and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Srinivasan Sivabalan

media:content.media:description: (Photo by YASSER AL-ZAYYAT/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: YASSER AL-ZAYYAT/AFP

item.title: Central Banks in Asia Are Becoming Wary of Currency Intervention
item.description: Some of emerging Asia’s biggest central banks look to be dialing back their interventions in the currency market.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Wong, Malavika Kaur Makol

media:content.media:description: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) logo on barrier tape at the central bank's headquarters building in Mumbai, India, on Friday, June 6, 2025. India's central bank cut interest rates more than projected and unexpectedly reduced the cash reserve ratio for banks, providing a major liquidity boost to the economy as growth prospects dim and inflation subsides.

item.title: Trump’s Airstrikes on Iran Leave Oil Market Braced for Surge
item.description: Oil traders are preparing for an oil-price surge when trading reopens, with the focus on whether Tehran’s retaliation to US airstrikes will lead to a disruption in crude flows that have been largely unaffected so far.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Yongchang Chin

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump walks on the South Lawn of the White House after arriving on Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, June 21, 2025. Trump often suggests that something will happen in "two weeks" when he's looking to buy himself some time. But his latest two-weeks declaration — on possible US military strikes in Iran — comes with unusually high stakes.

item.title: Robinhood CEO Vlad Tenev Wants to Change the Future of AI
item.description: The race to creating the most efficient and most intelligent AI programs has some unlikely contenders who are hoping to redefine specific industries through more advanced models. Robinhood’s Vlad Tenev is developing “mathematical superintelligence” for provable accuracy in math and science, while SandboxAQ’s Jack Hidary backs “large quantitative models” trained on numbers, not words. As billions flow into AI, the future may not be one-size-fits-all models like ChatGPT. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China Condemns Trump’s Iran Attack in First Comment Since US Hit
item.description: China criticized the US strike on Iranian nuclear facilities and again said it’s willing to join international efforts to restore peace in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, Yian Lee

media:content.media:description: A soldier stands in Tiananmen Square at the end of the flag raising ceremony as China marks the 75th anniversary of the founding of the Peoples Republic, in Beijing, China, on Tuesday, Oct. 1, 2024. President Xi Jinping urged caution in the face of what he said could be a rough patch ahead for China, in his first public comments since the government announced an unprecedented stimulus package. Photographer: Andrea Verdelli/Bloomberg

item.title: British, Singapore Airlines Halt Gulf Flights After Iran Strike
item.description: British Airways and Singapore Airlines canceled flights to the Persian Gulf, increasing aviation disruptions in the region after the US struck three nuclear sites in Iran and Tehran vowed to retaliate.
item.dc:creator: Leen Al-Rashdan

media:content.media:description: Passenger aircraft, operated by British Airways Plc, at Heathrow Airport Terminal 5, in London, UK, on Monday, Feb. 3, 2025. Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves said she wants construction work to begin on a third runway at Heathrow Airport before the next election is due in 2029, a day after giving the green light to a controversial project that’s divided her governing Labour Party.

item.title: Congo Adds Three Months to Cobalt Export Ban to Curb Supply
item.description: The Democratic Republic of Congo extended a temporary ban on cobalt exports by three months, according to a statement from a regulatory agency, prolonging its efforts to rein in a glut on the international market.
item.dc:creator: William Clowes

media:content.media:description: Sacks of cobalt powder on a truck for export at the Etoile mine, operated by Chemaf Sarl, in Katanga province near Lubumbashi, the Democratic Republic of Congo, on Wednesday, Dec. 22, 2021. Along a 250-mile highway which cuts through central Africa, thousands of flatbed trucks haul sheets of copper and sacks of cobalt hydroxide, essential for electric cars and other 21st century technologies for which drivers must pay steep tolls, as much as $900 for a round trip. Photographer: Lucien Kahozi/Bloomberg

item.title: Euro-Area Economy Needs More ECB Stimulus, Centeno Tells Stampa
item.description: The European Central Bank needs to provide the euro-area economy with “further stimulus,” Governing Council member Mario Centeno told Italy’s La Stampa.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss, Daniele Lepido

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the European Central Bank (ECB), in Frankfurt, Germany, on Tuesday, June 17, 2025. After cutting interest rates eight times in a year to bring inflation to around their 2% target, ECB policymakers are signaling they’re well positioned to tackle any sudden shifts in the economic backdrop.

item.title: US Strikes on Iran Come at Fragile Moment for the Global Economy
item.description: US strikes on Iran’s three main nuclear facilities come at a fragile moment for the global economy, and the outlook now hinges on how forcefully the Islamic Republic retaliates.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Donnan, Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Photo by ATTA KENARE/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: ATTA KENARE/AFP

item.title: Trump Gives National Address on Iran Airstrikes
item.description: President Donald Trump gave a national address Saturday evening speaking on the joint Israeli airstrikes in Iran. He said Iran's key nuclear enrichment facilities were “completely and totally obliterated” and that this bombing would be the most difficult by far. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump Speaks: "There Are Many Targets Left"
item.description: President Donald Trump gave a national address Saturday evening on the joint Israeli airstrike on Iran saying "Remember there are many targets left" and that this bombing would be the most difficult by far. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Netanyahu Congratulates President Trump
item.description: In a pre-recorded message, Israel’s Netanyahu expresses his gratitude to Trump and the US military. “In tonight’s action against Iran’s nuclear facilities, America has been truly unsurpassed. It’s done what no other country on earth could do," Netanyahu says. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump Congratulates Israel on Successful Joint Airstrike
item.description: President Donald Trump gave a national address Saturday evening congratulating Benjamin Netanyahu and the Israeli military on a successful airstrike mission on nuclear enrichment facilities in Iran. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Attacks Three Nuclear Sites in Iran, Widening Conflict
item.description: President Donald Trump says US strikes on Iran’s three main nuclear facilities had “completely and totally obliterated” them, and threatened further military action if Tehran did not make peace with Israel. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump Speaks on Military Strikes on Iran Nuclear Sites
item.description: President Donald Trump gave a national address Saturday evening saying "Iran's key nuclear enrichment facilities were “completely and totally obliterated.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Hong Kong Stock Rally Shakes Up Investor Playbook for China
item.description: Wall Street entered 2025 with bullish bets on onshore Chinese stocks, counting on Beijing’s stimulus drive to cushion the blow from US tariffs. Six months in, they couldn’t have been more wrong.
item.dc:creator: John Cheng, Hoi Yuet Woo

item.title: Summers on the Fed, Aramco Evolution, Future of AI, Themed Entertainment Industry | Wall Street Week
item.description: This week, Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers on the recent Fed decision and the economic implications of uncertainty in the Middle East. And, how is Saudi giant Aramco diversifying in a tech-driven world? Plus, an interview with Robinhood’s Vlad Tenev on artificial intelligence solutions for nuanced needs. Later, Netflix is entering the themed entertainment business with Netflix House, further intensifying its competition with traditional media players. (Source: Bloomberg)
